prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will use the FDM mode of the correlator with spectral averaging of 8 in order to reduce the data rate. The spectral resolution after averaging is ~10 km/s, which is much smaller than the proposed final binning of 40 km/s.

We require an angular resolution that is high enough to resolve the disk kinematics in the galaxies involved. De Breuck (2014) used a 0.4 arcsec (~3.2 kpc) resolution beam to resolve the kinematics in a similar IR bright galaxy at high-z, and we will use a slightly better resolution of 0.3 arcsec (~ 2.5 kpc) for this program. This resolution should be high enough to resolve disk wide structure (which is the aim of the current proposal), but low enough that we will be able to detect the flux with a reasonable integration time.

The typical line intensity for IR bright galaxies is ~3 mJy (e.g. Tacconi et al. 2008) with 1 arcsec resolution (8 kpc at z=1). Scaling this to the proposed 0.3 arcsec ALMA beam gives 0.27 mJy/beam. Assuming that the CO emission is contained in a 2 kpc region, which is the average size scale of similar IR bright galaxies at high-z (Simpson et al. 2015), the beam filling factor is 0.0625. Therefore we estimate a ~ 4mJy peak with this beam. We would like to detect these galaxies with at least S/N > 10, and thus the required sensitivity is 0.4 mJy for 40 km/s. The proposed velocity resolution is chosen so that the velocity structure can be investigated in 10 channels (for a 400 km/s line which is typical for these IR bright merging galaxies).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Galaxy mergers are a fundamental process that governs the evolution of galaxies in the universe, triggering nuclear/extended starburs and hosting powerful AGNs. The molecular gas properties in local interacting and merging U/LIRGs have been studied in depth over the past years, but only a limited set of data exists for high-z merging galaxies. In this regard, we propose 8.9 hours of ALMA observations to conduct a pilot survey in CO(2-1) toward 8 merging z=1 ULIRGs using 0.3" (2.4~kpc) resolution images taken in Band 3 of ALMA. The primary goal of this project is to investigate the molecular gas morphology, kinematics and the global properties in z=1 merging IR bright galaxies that are forming stars at 300 - 2000 Msun/yr, and quanitfy these parameters as a functrion of the merger stage and IR luminosity. In addition, we will compare these properties with the z=0 merging U/LIRGs and "main sequence" starburst galaxies at z=1. This will be a pioneering molecular gas survey specifically focusing on the evolution of interacting/merging galaxies at z=1, and we plan a higher resolution survey at this redshift as well as broader redshift bins in future cycles.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00099.S: Highest Priority 2011.0.00467.S: Highest Priority 2012.1.00280.S: Filler 2013.1.00080.S: Highest Priority
